Local politics now; Louisiana's Legislature has been meeting in a special session this week.
It's trying to develop a recovery plan following hurricanes Katrina and Rita.
The biggest challenge facing legislators is a billion-dollar state budget shortfall, and that's largely due to a decline in tax revenue after the storms.
As NPR's Adam Hochberg reports from Baton Rouge, there's little consensus on what to do about it.

When Governor Kathleen Blanco convened the special session Sunday night, she heralded it as an opportunity for state leaders to pull together to show the nation that Louisiana's government could come through this crisis strong and united.
It didn't take long for that idyllic vision to fall apart.
This caucus has filed suit against Kathleen Babineaux Blanco in her capacity as governor of the state of Louisiana.
Yesterday at the Capitol, the Legislative Black Caucus announced plans to take the governor to court.
Like the members of the caucus, Blanco is a Democrat, and generally has had a good relationship with African-American legislators.
But Representative Cedric Richmond says the caucus can't support the governor's program to address the budget shortfall, especially a series of deep spending cuts she's made in government programs.
We're talking about school-based health clinics.
We're talking about the Louisiana School of the Deaf.
We're talking about public education.
We're talking about Medicaid.
And especially in this tragic time, we cannot balance a budget on the backs of poor people and on the backs of the very people that were displaced.
The lawsuit challenges Blanco's right to enact spending cuts without legislative approval.
A state judge will consider the case next week, but in the meantime, it's complicated the governor's already difficult task of forging a budget compromise.
Blanco's idea has already had tepid support from Republicans, who complained she wasn't cutting spending enough.
Now Blanco also has to respond to charges from her own party that she's cut too much.
This is a tough session.
When you have a nearly $1 billion shortfall in a revenue stream, nobody's really happy.
But, you know, a governor has to do what a governor has to do.
Blanco says the cuts aren't personal, and she refutes the suggestion they're unfairly targeted at minorities or the poor.
Everybody is making sacrifices right now, and we're cutting all parts of government.
And so everybody is giving up a lot in every direction, and everybody's being asked to work harder with less resources.
While Blanco cuts spending on her own, she needs legislators' help to enact other parts of her emergency budget plan, like tapping into state reserve funds and borrowing money by issuing bonds.
The governor remains optimistic lawmakers will support those ideas, but time is running short.
The 17-day special session is scheduled to end in about a week and a half, and Louisiana political columnist John McGinnis doubts legislators will approve Blanco's full agenda by then.
It's impossible in a situation like this to say, `Everyone's going to come together and we're going to hold hands and we're going to come up with a consensus.
This is a real big, ambitious plan, and it won't be done in this 17-day session.

McGinnis says legislators may approve the less controversial parts of the governor's plan before Thanksgiving, but with much of her agenda now mired in political squabbles and lawsuits, there's a growing sense here that Louisiana's budget crisis may linger until the next special session in January.
Adam Hochberg, NPR News, Baton Rouge.

When writer and journalist Pamela Druckerman became a mother, she expected to spend the next few years frantically meeting her daughter's every demand.
But living abroad in Paris, she found a whole new method of parenting, one she shares in a new book.
Critic Marcela Valdes has this report.
In the U.S., after all, mealtimes, living rooms, and sleep schedules typically turn to chaos as soon as a baby arrives.
But as an American in Paris, Druckerman noticed a series of what she calls minor miracles: Parents who enjoy long adult conversations while their children play quietly nearby.
And perhaps most surprising of all, babies - lots of them - who sleep through the night at just two or three months old.
Scenes like these inspired Druckerman to write her marvelous new book ""Bringing Up Bebe."" Druckerman has investigated and distilled the essentials of French childrearing.
First among them is the French belief that even babies are rational creatures with a capacity to learn self-control.
Second is their conviction that it's better for everyone, parents and kids, if children adapt to adult routines.
As one French psychologist explains, the child must learn from a very young age that he's not alone in the world and that there's a time for everything.
Druckerman provides fascinating details about French sleep training, feeding schedules and family rituals.
But her book's real pleasures spring from her funny, self-deprecating stories.
One of the book's few flaws is her tendency to downplay the role government has had in cultivating parents' so-called intuition.
Is it really a coincidence that the Parisian way of introducing solid foods matches the instructions in a government pamphlet?
And she only hints at the ways French schools inhibit creativity as children grow older.
Surrounded by adults who can't resist gobbling their own slices of cake, children could hardly be expected to do any better.
Marcela Valdes is a board-member of the National Book Critic's Circle.
